We proceed new to notice the second part OF the
Report OF the Committee Of the House Of Repre-
\. natives, on the expectancy OF Railway from
Boston TO the Hudson river. The Committee say


The subject Of improving the facilities Of inter
course between Boston and the interior has been
long growing in Importance and has now become
~ vast interest to the State. It has increased in
magnitude in nroportion the sno'c of our minfprS
ha. heen diminished our mana featuring establish
,nppfs muffippd, nnd neD channel to direct the
trddp Of this Commonwealth into other States
made


For many years previous to tho present season,
he snow Of our winters 10 Massachusetts, has been
rsdually diminished. Instead Of seighing for
tour months in winter, it is now rare for so many
weeks and in the neighborhood OF Boston. during
The twelve years previous TO the present, the guam
tity has not upon an average been more than suf
cirnt for two weeks. This change in our seasons,
which afiotds interesting topic for the philoso
phrr has greatly diminished the means Of trans
po,taion Our winters have often been wet; our
Dads have been rendered so!t, and nearly impassa
hIf lr heavy loaded teams; and this has occur
| red Al that season OF the year. when the great ag.
ticul n.al interest has most required the means OF
inte course with the market. The cultivaors du-
/ ING The summer season, is engaged on bis farm,
and he has no produce except oi the lighter kind
rescv Tor the market, nor time to transport u he
|
seticles Of produce are prepared for the market,
our roads have h en- ln such state as TO render
transpo, alton difficult and expensive. For the want
! ot A fferent mode OF transportation, the winter
season in Massachusetts. and in all our northern
Ststes has been passed in comparative idleness -
This time Of the farmer during that season, could
in no way be so pro6taby employed as in conveying
produce, wood, lumber building Materials etc. 10
market, if suitable facilities for transportation were
afforded And from the increase OF business. which
a short time of sleighing produces, It has been
computed by intelligent agricultursts and mer.
chants that more than three tmes the number oil
ton. would be transported duriug the year. II these
facilities we're provided.


The increase of our manufacturing establish
ments, through the interior, has likewise created
an additional demand Of no ordinary magnitude,
for improving the means Of intercourse with the
capits, of the State. The immense benefits which
would accrue to these establishments by the con-
struction Of an easy, constant. cheap' ana e*peai-
tous mode Of conveyance at all seasons oil the year
cen hardly be estimated.


The facilities OF conveyance IN England nave
contributed essentially to advance the CROWN and
prospetty OF their manufactures and have enabled
them 10 compete so successfully with those OF other
nations Until we adopt the same policy IN this
re pect. our manufactures must continue TO main
tain an unequal contest.


i The contemplated canals, and the improvements
of the navigation Of rivers, are objects OF great
importance 10 the public. These improvements
will enrich The many towns in their vicinity; and


the wealth and prosperity of any part OF the State,


is the wealth and prosperity of the whole But


then i. must be obvious. that canal will be closed
bv frost nearly FIVE months oil the year, when It is
most wanted. IF during that important part OF the
wear, a cheap and easy mode Of conveyance should
be opened from the interior to the seabord. II would
afford additional advantages to the public. II would
rive choice Of markets TO the farmer, the meT

and 1856 feet 10 inches back which has been occupied

buildings thereon, the one occupied stable, and the
other store

BIZ THE REV. THOMAS DALE
once more clasp thee to my breast,
Child of my first and fondest love,
Ere YET enter into rest,


Ere JON the ransomed hosts above:
And earlhward though my thoughts must rove
From Sal"ts and Seraphs bending there,
Who shall parting sigh reptove
Ger one as pure and scarce less farl
My bud OF beauty thou must bloom,
Mid the chill rains, and wintry blast,
Where skies are wrapt in starless gloom,
AND summer suns have beamed their last,
yet though dark clouds the heaven osercast.
lie, at whose word the winds are still,
Can screen thee till the storm be past.
Ikrow He CALL trust he will
Yet, who shall form thine infan, sghs
To syllable the first brief prayer'
And who shall point thee to the skies
And say, Thou hast a Father there
And who shall watch with ccaseless care
Lest thy young STEPS unheeding stray
Where Pleasure plants the secret snare
And Hopes seductive smiles betray?
Oh could bear thee hence, while vet,
The strife of passion is unknown,
Ere guilt her fatal seal hath set


Or earth has mark'd thee for its own,-..
While Natute's debt Of death alone
Is all mortality must pay


To gaze upon the eternal throne,
And swell The glad unceasng lay!
But now leave thee-not alone
More welcome far were solitude,
For tie, who ne'er forsakes his own,
Zen in the desert, vast and rude,
Night bid the ravens bring thee food,
Or streams gush forth amidst the Wild
Or guide the wanderings of the good
To seek and save his landmaid's child.
leave thee 10 thy mothers foes,


leave thee TO the foes of Heaven -
Yet d. leave thee but to those r.
Lord be The guilty thought forgiven!
O. If she strive as have striyen,
With stormy winds on lfe's rough sea,
May she by warning waves be driven
To find haven, Lord, with thee!
WILMINGTON, Del FRIDAY, MARCH o 1927.

From The AMULET for 1877.
THE MARTYRS CHILD.
By THE REV. TnomAs Da1r

E 10th of next month, for printing and furnishing, in
complete ORDER three hundred copies of the Journal Il" the

with 1850 ms each page plea type, and in the order
of the Journal the Senate of the said Sta for the
1925. HENRY STOUT.

TO the Printers of Delaware.

description could be sent with despatch. and at all
seasons as soon as prepared and to the market
where the various commodities would bring the
highest price. 1t would obviae the necessity and
expense OF storing various, and frequently perisha
Bile articles; circumstance alike important to the
owner and consumer. 1t would benefit all the con-


emplaed canals, and the navigation OF our rivers,
by increasing the general amount 10 be transported;
and it would save much Of the trade within own
State. And if equal, or higher prices be obtain
ed within territories, an additional a1yan.
tage would accrue to the whole Commonwealth.


These and other reasons which might be men
toned, have operated TO produce strong and an
increasing conviction in the public mind that some
decisive measures are necessary to facilitate the
intercourse between Boston and the Hudson river a
or near Albany. 1t is measure which His Excel
lency the Governor has repeatedly urged upon the
attention Of the Legislature. The necessity Of The
measure has been cvinced by the appointment Of
Board OF Commissioners to explore route for
canal; evinced by the general anxiety felt for the
success of that enterprise, and the regret that
more favorable route could not have been ascertain
ed. 1t has been recently eyinced by repeated meet
| ings and resolves in various parts oil the Common
wealth and also by highly respectable petitions.
signed by some of the most intelligent, influential
and wealthy citizens n the community.


| The committee then review the two means
| of inter communication which have been most
though, Of, levels and railways, and after candid
examination of the advantages, expenses, &c OF
| each, come to the conclusion that the latter is pre-
fcrsble The irst cost OF an iron Railway, with
two sets of tracks, is less than that Of canal,
and the expense of repairs essentially iess.-The
cost OF the Quincy Railway is stated at 8l1 o52 90
cts. q mile, which is believed to be a third more
Than like undertaking would now cost.


In answer to the Circular appended TO this Re
| port, your Committee have received estimates Of
the amount of tonnage from between thirty and for
ty towns, in the five western counties oi this Com
mon wealth.-From Of the largest towns no
returns have been received. and Of course are not
estimated. The average amount Of tonnage IN each


town returned, is upwards of five hundred and fifty
eight tons annually And the conviction appears
general ,ha. should the price Of transportation be
reduced, great and increasing addition would be
made to this amount. The returns also state, with
very few exceptions, that The land to be occupied by
the Railway would be given.


i The navigation Of the Hudson River from Alba
ny to New York is upon average suspended by
ice one fourth part of the year. And this circum
stance would contribute, in no small degree, TO in
crease the extent Of business upon the contempls
ted road. The transportation OF passengers end
mails would add TO it.-Stages are no. SO liable 10
accidents upon Railway as upon common road


while their speed can be greatly increased A con
venience not afforded by canals.


I The extensive advantages OF opening canal be-





and national point of view, have already been pre-
sented to the Legislature. And II 80 great advan
taees would result from canal it is safe to con-
cude that much greater advantages would be real
lied by tha construction OF Railway, and at d.
minished expenditure.


The extension Of the proposed Railway from the
western line of Massachusetts, 10 the Hudson.
is a measure, which your Committee believe will


meet the enlightened views and receive the cordial
co operation of the government OF the State OF
New York. In support o! this opinion they refer
; to the letter Of His Excellency De Witt Clinton.
marked B. The public journals in the nelehbor-
hood Of the Hudson have already expressed live
ly interes, in this enterprise ard no opposition can
be apprchended from the liberal policy which actu
, stes our sister State.


From these considerations, your Committee are
satisfied of the Practicability and convinced of
the E1 pedisncy of constructing Railway from


Boston to the Hudson, the cost OF which can 10 their


opinion be accurately estimated only after actual sur
yey.
!, In closing their report. your Committee would
earnestly express their deep sense of the impor-
tance Of the design. which has been submitted to
their consideratc vestigation. design. intended
to procure for Massachusetts the enjoyment OF the
products OF her territory, the interest OF her
own capital the intercourse Of her own population,
the accumulation of her own resources; design
worthy the attention of free and powerful com


munity, worthy the mature and deliberate consd


Grafton Of an enlightened Legislature, and worthy
the active enterprise Of an American S'ate; de


SIGN too important in its results and too beneficial ia
its consequences to be lightly laid aside; tco honor


able to the character of Massachusetts, 1t capable
Of successful accomplishment, to be abandoned
without careful and accurate inquiry. Guided
by these views, your Committee would respectfully
recommend the adoption Of the following
RESOLVES s.


RScoT,,pd That the Governor OF this Common

CONDITIONS OF THE WATCHMAN

Philadelphia, February ai.-On Monday last,
John Porter. Coroner of Gloucester county. New
Jersey, held an inquest over the body OF female,
lound near Cooper's Creek, on the Jersey side Of
the Deleware. No ks Of violence appearing on
the body, the inquest were Of opinion, that she came
to her death by drowning. She was recognized 10
be the same person who was domestic in the lam
lily Of Mr.. Michael Ritter, and was supposed have
fallen into the Delaware at Callowhill street wharf
10 November last. She was yesterday handed over
by the Coroner TO her parents. and was buried in
respectable manner.

the tin Of the nose the end OF the tail killed
about seventeen miles from his place, a lew weeks
since by Mr.. David Hover. About the hour OF
10, the night previous. he was aroused from his
sumbcrs by the cries o! his dog and rising he went
TO the front door Of his house to ascertain the cause
He Judged rightly that the faithful animal had fallen
prey to some wild beast and again retired TO rest
The ne xt morning. having assembled some Of his
neighbors they joined in pursuit. Not more than
three hundred yards from the house having crossed
gully and accidentally looking back, he esped the
panther crouched upon he half devourcd carcasc OF
his dog He fred, and killed it. 1t is conJectured
that the great quantity of snow upon the mountains.
has forced them to the plains in quest OF iood
An explosion Of large quantity OF gunpowder
took place in the government stores al Port au
Prince on The Cd Of February, by which the Com
mssary of the Navy several officers, and about go
men were killed. The accident was osc asioned by
using iron hammers and iron nails in boxing up
1000 casks to put on board government vessel.
President Boyer had left the store but . short ms
previous. BY the exertions OF the crews of TWO
French men Of war, with thsr FIRE engines, the city
was saved from destruction.

.Musterious aGair.-A little son of Benjamin
C,.rL of Arkansas, between three and four years
Of age. disappeared in mysterious manner, ia
Octoper, 1925, and supposed 10 have hsen
drowned, Notwithstanding little negro glr about
his own age said he was aiken away BY man on
horseback. Recently the parents received letter.
stating that their child would be delivered TO them
;r th-y ,Uonld enclose ESQ in q letter to Thomas
Tu,ty. at Natchsz The rpotber repaired to Natchez
and throu the aid Of the postmaster, succeeded IN
appvshending the pretended Thomas Iulty' whose
real nams was Edward H. Norris an ir,shmsn aud
scboolmas,er. He was committed TO JAIL and re-
fuses TO discover the place where the child IS
The country around has been searchse' and Ssoo
reward offered for the child

being accidentally shot by Jesse c. Earle


The following account Of this very affecting accident we
copy from the Chronicle :-"As Mr.. Jesse G. Eaes
Surgical instrument Maker. IF this city, was yesterday
making preparation to go shooting, he took iowling
piece which had been in the habit Of hiring persons,
and which had been uniformly returned without load


He put small charge Of powder into the piece, and after
having pinned it. attempted to fire il but The gun fasheds
when ne took gun pick and after clearing the touch
hole, put in prming, and again drew the trigger,
Of shot, which without his knowledge in it, lodg-
ed in the body of the of MIR. II w Tilsard, Lom-
bard street, child about years old who just enter
child died ely, and on examination it found


that ten shots had entered the heart Of the innocent sue

PHILADELPHIA, Feb 21.-A FIRE broke out last night, be-
II and l2 o'clock. in Elijah Ches'ons coacnakers
,royed, together with number of unfinished carriages,
&C. and the backsmh's shop in the Insurance was
effected tie dwelling bonse of Mr. cheston, which IS
considerably damaged, but his shop and its
tents We regret say that Mr. Chesons loss has been
seyere-about $4,000 We assured lila, fire had
been in the shop after three o'clock This fire was doubt,
less the work of incendary. Five six dwelling tou.
ses have been materially injured having their roofs
destroyed. There much destruction otturni,nre.

The subject Of improving the facilities Of inter
course between Boston and the interior has been
long growing in Importance and has now become
~ vast interest to the State. It has increased in
magnitude in nroportion the sno'c of our minfprS
ha. heen diminished our mana featuring establish
,nppfs muffippd, nnd neD channel to direct the
trddp Of this Commonwealth into other States
made


For many years previous to tho present season,
he snow Of our winters 10 Massachusetts, has been
rsdually diminished. Instead Of seighing for
tour months in winter, it is now rare for so many
weeks and in the neighborhood OF Boston. during
The twelve years previous TO the present, the guam
tity has not upon an average been more than suf
cirnt for two weeks. This change in our seasons,
which afiotds interesting topic for the philoso
phrr has greatly diminished the means Of trans
po,taion Our winters have often been wet; our
Dads have been rendered so!t, and nearly impassa
hIf lr heavy loaded teams; and this has occur
| red Al that season OF the year. when the great ag.
ticul n.al interest has most required the means OF
inte course with the market. The cultivaors du-
/ ING The summer season, is engaged on bis farm,
and he has no produce except oi the lighter kind
rescv Tor the market, nor time to transport u he
|
seticles Of produce are prepared for the market,
our roads have h en- ln such state as TO render
transpo, alton difficult and expensive. For the want
! ot A fferent mode OF transportation, the winter
season in Massachusetts. and in all our northern
Ststes has been passed in comparative idleness -
This time Of the farmer during that season, could
in no way be so pro6taby employed as in conveying
produce, wood, lumber building Materials etc. 10
market, if suitable facilities for transportation were
afforded And from the increase OF business. which
a short time of sleighing produces, It has been
computed by intelligent agricultursts and mer.
chants that more than three tmes the number oil
ton. would be transported duriug the year. II these
facilities we're provided.


The increase of our manufacturing establish
ments, through the interior, has likewise created
an additional demand Of no ordinary magnitude,
for improving the means Of intercourse with the
capits, of the State. The immense benefits which
would accrue to these establishments by the con-
struction Of an easy, constant. cheap' ana e*peai-
tous mode Of conveyance at all seasons oil the year
cen hardly be estimated.


The facilities OF conveyance IN England nave
contributed essentially to advance the CROWN and
prospetty OF their manufactures and have enabled
them 10 compete so successfully with those OF other
nations Until we adopt the same policy IN this
re pect. our manufactures must continue TO main
tain an unequal contest.


i The contemplated canals, and the improvements
of the navigation Of rivers, are objects OF great
importance 10 the public. These improvements
will enrich The many towns in their vicinity; and


the wealth and prosperity of any part OF the State,


is the wealth and prosperity of the whole But


then i. must be obvious. that canal will be closed
bv frost nearly FIVE months oil the year, when It is
most wanted. IF during that important part OF the
wear, a cheap and easy mode Of conveyance should
be opened from the interior to the seabord. II would
afford additional advantages to the public. II would
rive choice Of markets TO the farmer, the meT

full articles.headline:
WILMINGTON, Del FRIDAY, MARCH o 1927.

From The AMULET for 1877.
THE MARTYRS CHILD.
full articles.article:
BIZ THE REV. THOMAS DALE
once more clasp thee to my breast,
Child of my first and fondest love,
Ere YET enter into rest,


Ere JON the ransomed hosts above:
And earlhward though my thoughts must rove
From Sal"ts and Seraphs bending there,
Who shall parting sigh reptove
Ger one as pure and scarce less farl
My bud OF beauty thou must bloom,
Mid the chill rains, and wintry blast,
Where skies are wrapt in starless gloom,
AND summer suns have beamed their last,
yet though dark clouds the heaven osercast.
lie, at whose word the winds are still,
Can screen thee till the storm be past.
Ikrow He CALL trust he will
Yet, who shall form thine infan, sghs
To syllable the first brief prayer'
And who shall point thee to the skies
And say, Thou hast a Father there
And who shall watch with ccaseless care
Lest thy young STEPS unheeding stray
Where Pleasure plants the secret snare
And Hopes seductive smiles betray?
Oh could bear thee hence, while vet,
The strife of passion is unknown,
Ere guilt her fatal seal hath set


Or earth has mark'd thee for its own,-..
While Natute's debt Of death alone
Is all mortality must pay


To gaze upon the eternal throne,
And swell The glad unceasng lay!
But now leave thee-not alone
More welcome far were solitude,
For tie, who ne'er forsakes his own,
Zen in the desert, vast and rude,
Night bid the ravens bring thee food,
Or streams gush forth amidst the Wild
Or guide the wanderings of the good
To seek and save his landmaid's child.
leave thee 10 thy mothers foes,


leave thee TO the foes of Heaven -
Yet d. leave thee but to those r.
Lord be The guilty thought forgiven!
O. If she strive as have striyen,
With stormy winds on lfe's rough sea,
May she by warning waves be driven
To find haven, Lord, with thee!

full articles.headline: TO the Printers of Delaware.
full articles.article:
PROPOSALS will be received, at any time before the
E 10th of next month, for printing and furnishing, in
complete ORDER three hundred copies of the Journal Il" the
Senate of the State of Delaw The January Sessl"

with 1850 ms each page plea type, and in the order
of the Journal the Senate of the said Sta for the
1925. HENRY STOUT.


Dover Feb. 81, 1897. S2-4t

description could be sent with despatch. and at all
seasons as soon as prepared and to the market
where the various commodities would bring the
highest price. 1t would obviae the necessity and
expense OF storing various, and frequently perisha
Bile articles; circumstance alike important to the
owner and consumer. 1t would benefit all the con-


emplaed canals, and the navigation OF our rivers,
by increasing the general amount 10 be transported;
and it would save much Of the trade within own
State. And if equal, or higher prices be obtain
ed within territories, an additional a1yan.
tage would accrue to the whole Commonwealth.


These and other reasons which might be men
toned, have operated TO produce strong and an
increasing conviction in the public mind that some
decisive measures are necessary to facilitate the
intercourse between Boston and the Hudson river a
or near Albany. 1t is measure which His Excel
lency the Governor has repeatedly urged upon the
attention Of the Legislature. The necessity Of The
measure has been cvinced by the appointment Of
Board OF Commissioners to explore route for
canal; evinced by the general anxiety felt for the
success of that enterprise, and the regret that
more favorable route could not have been ascertain
ed. 1t has been recently eyinced by repeated meet
| ings and resolves in various parts oil the Common
wealth and also by highly respectable petitions.
signed by some of the most intelligent, influential
and wealthy citizens n the community.


| The committee then review the two means
| of inter communication which have been most
though, Of, levels and railways, and after candid
examination of the advantages, expenses, &c OF
| each, come to the conclusion that the latter is pre-
fcrsble The irst cost OF an iron Railway, with
two sets of tracks, is less than that Of canal,
and the expense of repairs essentially iess.-The
cost OF the Quincy Railway is stated at 8l1 o52 90
cts. q mile, which is believed to be a third more
Than like undertaking would now cost.


In answer to the Circular appended TO this Re
| port, your Committee have received estimates Of
the amount of tonnage from between thirty and for
ty towns, in the five western counties oi this Com
mon wealth.-From Of the largest towns no
returns have been received. and Of course are not
estimated. The average amount Of tonnage IN each


town returned, is upwards of five hundred and fifty
eight tons annually And the conviction appears
general ,ha. should the price Of transportation be
reduced, great and increasing addition would be
made to this amount. The returns also state, with
very few exceptions, that The land to be occupied by
the Railway would be given.


i The navigation Of the Hudson River from Alba
ny to New York is upon average suspended by
ice one fourth part of the year. And this circum
stance would contribute, in no small degree, TO in
crease the extent Of business upon the contempls
ted road. The transportation OF passengers end
mails would add TO it.-Stages are no. SO liable 10
accidents upon Railway as upon common road


while their speed can be greatly increased A con
venience not afforded by canals.


I The extensive advantages OF opening canal be-





and national point of view, have already been pre-
sented to the Legislature. And II 80 great advan
taees would result from canal it is safe to con-
cude that much greater advantages would be real
lied by tha construction OF Railway, and at d.
minished expenditure.


The extension Of the proposed Railway from the
western line of Massachusetts, 10 the Hudson.
is a measure, which your Committee believe will


meet the enlightened views and receive the cordial
co operation of the government OF the State OF
New York. In support o! this opinion they refer
; to the letter Of His Excellency De Witt Clinton.
marked B. The public journals in the nelehbor-
hood Of the Hudson have already expressed live
ly interes, in this enterprise ard no opposition can
be apprchended from the liberal policy which actu
, stes our sister State.


From these considerations, your Committee are
satisfied of the Practicability and convinced of
the E1 pedisncy of constructing Railway from


Boston to the Hudson, the cost OF which can 10 their


opinion be accurately estimated only after actual sur
yey.
!, In closing their report. your Committee would
earnestly express their deep sense of the impor-
tance Of the design. which has been submitted to
their consideratc vestigation. design. intended
to procure for Massachusetts the enjoyment OF the
products OF her territory, the interest OF her
own capital the intercourse Of her own population,
the accumulation of her own resources; design
worthy the attention of free and powerful com


munity, worthy the mature and deliberate consd


Grafton Of an enlightened Legislature, and worthy
the active enterprise Of an American S'ate; de


SIGN too important in its results and too beneficial ia
its consequences to be lightly laid aside; tco honor


able to the character of Massachusetts, 1t capable
Of successful accomplishment, to be abandoned
without careful and accurate inquiry. Guided
by these views, your Committee would respectfully
recommend the adoption Of the following
RESOLVES s.


RScoT,,pd That the Governor OF this Common


,u~.ltl hv und with the cnnsert of the Council, be

Philadelphia, February ai.-On Monday last,
John Porter. Coroner of Gloucester county. New
Jersey, held an inquest over the body OF female,
lound near Cooper's Creek, on the Jersey side Of
the Deleware. No ks Of violence appearing on
the body, the inquest were Of opinion, that she came
to her death by drowning. She was recognized 10
be the same person who was domestic in the lam
lily Of Mr.. Michael Ritter, and was supposed have
fallen into the Delaware at Callowhill street wharf
10 November last. She was yesterday handed over
by the Coroner TO her parents. and was buried in
respectable manner.

the tin Of the nose the end OF the tail killed
about seventeen miles from his place, a lew weeks
since by Mr.. David Hover. About the hour OF
10, the night previous. he was aroused from his
sumbcrs by the cries o! his dog and rising he went
TO the front door Of his house to ascertain the cause
He Judged rightly that the faithful animal had fallen
prey to some wild beast and again retired TO rest
The ne xt morning. having assembled some Of his
neighbors they joined in pursuit. Not more than
three hundred yards from the house having crossed
gully and accidentally looking back, he esped the

An explosion Of large quantity OF gunpowder
took place in the government stores al Port au
Prince on The Cd Of February, by which the Com
mssary of the Navy several officers, and about go
men were killed. The accident was osc asioned by
using iron hammers and iron nails in boxing up
1000 casks to put on board government vessel.
President Boyer had left the store but . short ms
previous. BY the exertions OF the crews of TWO
French men Of war, with thsr FIRE engines, the city
was saved from destruction.

.Musterious aGair.-A little son of Benjamin
C,.rL of Arkansas, between three and four years
Of age. disappeared in mysterious manner, ia

stating that their child would be delivered TO them
;r th-y ,Uonld enclose ESQ in q letter to Thomas

and throu the aid Of the postmaster, succeeded IN

real nams was Edward H. Norris an ir,shmsn aud

fuses TO discover the place where the child IS
The country around has been searchse' and Ssoo

The following account Of this very affecting accident we
copy from the Chronicle :-"As Mr.. Jesse G. Eaes
Surgical instrument Maker. IF this city, was yesterday
making preparation to go shooting, he took iowling
piece which had been in the habit Of hiring persons,
and which had been uniformly returned without load


He put small charge Of powder into the piece, and after
having pinned it. attempted to fire il but The gun fasheds
when ne took gun pick and after clearing the touch
hole, put in prming, and again drew the trigger,
Of shot, which without his knowledge in it, lodg-
ed in the body of the of MIR. II w Tilsard, Lom-
bard street, child about years old who just enter
child died ely, and on examination it found


that ten shots had entered the heart Of the innocent sue
rer'
